Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2020
Data:
Value: A. Worth every penny—I can’t stress this enough. We’re already saving usage on our electric bill (switched from incandescent on overloaded dimmer switches).

What we bought: 48 individually bulbs (3 came with the Hub + remote) and 2 sets of the Hue Play. Everything is on one Hub on and connectivity is great.

Happiness factor: A+. What a wonderland we’ve created. It’s worth the money for some daily LED bliss!

Install/Setup: A. Easy to install, Philips Hue app found every single bulb and all I had to do was name them and assign them to rooms and zones. I also bought a few remotes that I mounted to light switches to control Upstairs zone and Downstairs zone, respectively.

Accessories: B. The accessories don’t fix people touching the switches and resetting scenes, et al. If you want to stop your family from touching the lights switches, buy the Lutron Aurora wireless rotary dimmers (Hue, HomeKit compatible) and snap them over your light switches. Has made the world of difference in teaching everyone to use the Hue-compatible dimmers vs. the originals.

Data:
I'm happy with my new lights. Been running them for about a year, and the only negative that I have to say about them is that it's hard to balance between a high lumen output. You don't want too blue, and you don't want too yellow, and it's hard to find that in-between. I got these because I love to have the ability to change to a color of my choice to help with things like sleep, migraines, and motivation.

Several studies, including one conducted in 2016, found that green light significantly decreased light sensitivity and reduced the intensity of headaches in migraine sufferers. In contrast, blue light, which is prevalent in many modern light sources like LED screens, has been shown to exacerbate migraine pain due to its higher energy and shorter wavelength.

When I wake up in the morning I like to have the lights a nice soft-blue, at 25-40% brightness, until my eyes can adjust. With these lights and the app that PH has, it's easy. You can even set timers to make the lights fade-in, so it's not a sudden blast as soon as your alarm clock goes off. Other times I don't want to turn the lights completely off because I want to watch a movie and still be able to see around the room when I need to get up and use the bathroom or something without opening the app to turn the lights back on or up brighter. So, in that instance, i sent the light to a dim blue light at 8-10% brightness. The real problem with these LED lights lies in the app, which is a bit slow when it comes to connecting to the lights each time you open the app, but it gets there, just have to be patient. Every time you open the app it will do a remote connection to each light individually, and check their status, essentially. Sometimes it happens where the app will see 2 of the LED light bulbs, but the third one it just doesn't connect to for ~30 seconds. Sometimes you even have to fully close the app then try to ping that light again.

The physical size difference between a standard light bulb and the PH LED bulbs is noticeable but barely an issue; They fit just fine. They're just slightly taller or same size as other compact LEDs and traditional filament bulbs, but shorter than the A21.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2022
Data:
I can’t say enough how much I can’t stand Alexa with smart lights. It is honestly the worst “smart” anything I have ever used. Alexa can control smart lights like an infant can control their bowel movements.

I have tried multiple companies, multiples lights, wyze, Phillips, Sengled and after 6 months of Alexa losing connectivity and constantly have to reset, re-pair, reboot wifi, reboot Alexa, reboot life, I finally found the issue.

It is ALEXA!!

Alexa is an awful, absolutely awful way to make your home “smart”.

I’ll give you an example. When I finally got my fill of “cheap” lights like Sengled, I decided to try the higher priced lights, Phillips in this case.

Highly rated, great lights. “Work with Alexa only, no hub needed!”.

Sounds to good to be true? Yes! Because it is!

I added all my Phillips lights, everything was perfect. All my routines for sunset and sunrise were working.

It was as great as the Sengled lights were, for about 1 week. THEN, just like with any smart light you will pair with Alexa, connectivity is lost. ALWAYS, LOST. ALWAYS!

No matter what you do. Lost.

Sent Amazon customer support a message. No help.
Sent Phillips a message, they said the issue was with Alexa. Same as Sengled said!!

I immediately returned the Phillips lights and then what happens. When you add ANY Phillips light to Alexa, it will stay with you until you die.

I tried to delete the lights from Phillips. They said the issue is with Alexa. I contacted Amazon. They said the issue is with Phillips!!!

So now, EVERY TIME I add ONE smart light, ALL EIGHT of the old Phillips lights try to re add AGAIN!

So instead of one device being added, it’s NINE LIGHTS. I have to delete any time I change anything on Alexa. ANY DANG TIME.

If I lose connective and fix it, 9 lights.
If I have to add them again, 9 lights.

So if you want to purchase a smart lighting system, stay AWAY from Sengled and stay AWAY from ALEXA.

Alexa is good at telling you the time. Not making your house “smart”. It will surely make your house “dumb” though.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2022
Data:
Ever since I went to a large electronics retail store near me to get something totally different than these bulbs and saw the Philips Hue demonstrated in concert with what I was looking for, I was hooked on them. I have them throughout my home and have them in my office at work. I have about 30 of them in my house and 10 of them in my office. To say the least, I am more than satisfied with the Philips Hue products.

Now the review…

Philips have been making bulbs for many years and then when they broke into the industry of smart wifi bulbs, they became quite the hit. Pair the hue bulbs with the Hue Bridge and the app, one’s creative side can really shine.

The Build Quality.

These bulbs have a little heft to them whereas there is a lot of technology that needs to be crammed into a space the size … well the size of a light bulb. The build quality in my opinion is pretty solid and done well. The illumination part diffuses the LEDs used in these bulbs are very smooth and do not see any hot spots whatsoever from the LEDS inside. The colors produced from the RGB LEDS are pretty rich and vibrant but as in every RGB style bulb, the light output will vary from color to color and different white temperatures. Case in point. If you choose the bulbs to light up in blue, the overall Lumens factor will be less than if you choose to use Yellow or other bright colors of the spectrum. But if you go with the white ambiance aspect, the whites will pretty much be equal in Lumens factor from the lower temperature like 2700K to the higher temperatures like 6500k.

Features.

These bulbs are full of them when you connect them with the Hue bridge. You can have them turn on and off with the use of Google Home, Assistant or Alexa. You can turn them on or off with the use of the user-friendly app and even turn them on or off when you are out and about as long as you have the app connected to the cloud server set up within your smart home. You can set up various different scenes as long as you have multiple Hue Bulbs. Scenes really don’t look great or seems simplistic if you have just one bulb. To get the best results, I recommend 5 or more of the Hue Bulbs in a room to get the different color scenes to show off well. (Refer to the bedroom pic I posted with this review.)
The latest versions of the Hue Bulbs can be operated via Bluetooth on the dedicated Bluetooth version of the Hue app. So, with bulbs having the Bluetooth technology, you do not need to have the Hue Bridge. The downside to that is you will not be able to set up multiple rooms and you can only control 10 Hue Bulbs via Bluetooth vs. up to 50 Hue Bulbs with using the Hue Bridge.
If there is anything that would be considered a downfall to these bulbs, is they are a bit on the pricy side. I have a few thousand dollars invested in my Hue Echo System and love everything about these bulbs. That would be the only flaw I can find with them.

The Recap.

These are some of the top of the line of smart bulbs. Can you find cheaper bulbs as far as costs is concerned? Yes, you can. But the saying goes, “You get what you pay for.” And that holds true with these bulbs. If you are willing to invest into the Hue System, you won’t be disappointed.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2024
Data:
I'm happy with my new lights. Been running them for about a year, and the only negative that I have to say about them is that it's hard to balance between a high lumen output. You don't want too blue, and you don't want too yellow, and it's hard to find that in-between. I got these because I love to have the ability to change to a color of my choice to help with things like sleep, migraines, and motivation.

Several studies, including one conducted in 2016, found that green light significantly decreased light sensitivity and reduced the intensity of headaches in migraine sufferers. In contrast, blue light, which is prevalent in many modern light sources like LED screens, has been shown to exacerbate migraine pain due to its higher energy and shorter wavelength.

When I wake up in the morning I like to have the lights a nice soft-blue, at 25-40% brightness, until my eyes can adjust. With these lights and the app that PH has, it's easy. You can even set timers to make the lights fade-in, so it's not a sudden blast as soon as your alarm clock goes off. Other times I don't want to turn the lights completely off because I want to watch a movie and still be able to see around the room when I need to get up and use the bathroom or something without opening the app to turn the lights back on or up brighter. So, in that instance, i sent the light to a dim blue light at 8-10% brightness. The real problem with these LED lights lies in the app, which is a bit slow when it comes to connecting to the lights each time you open the app, but it gets there, just have to be patient. Every time you open the app it will do a remote connection to each light individually, and check their status, essentially. Sometimes it happens where the app will see 2 of the LED light bulbs, but the third one it just doesn't connect to for ~30 seconds. Sometimes you even have to fully close the app then try to ping that light again.

The physical size difference between a standard light bulb and the PH LED bulbs is noticeable but barely an issue; They fit just fine. They're just slightly taller or same size as other compact LEDs and traditional filament bulbs, but shorter than the A21.

Data:
I love these lights, I use 6 A19 bulbs and 4 BR30 bulbs for the kitchen. I have the 6 bulbs spread between 2 bedrooms and a bathroom.
I started getting these in 2018, and have bought a couple more each year. So far, I have had no issues. I see some low reviews for Google Assistant, I can't say anything on the Google stuff - I use the Hue Hub and Echo Show/Echo dots.

Using Hue Hub and Echo, I've so far never had a connection issue with these bulbs, like I have had with cheaper bulbs I tried in the past. I have bedroom lights set to turn on when my alarm goes off, and they have never failed so far. Echo and Hub both find the lights right away, and I can set routines with either app. I never bothered to look at the instructions the bulbs come with, if you have connected any smart devices to apps before, there isn't much to it. Turn on the bulb, and Echo/Hub will find it. Just note that if you have a power outage, the bulbs will typically turn themselves ON when power is back...that can be a little jarring at 3am! You can also set the bulb to remember it's last setting, so if you flick off/on the light switch (normally leave the switch ON all the time), it will turn on at the same color/brightness it was last.

I use the base wattage bulbs, and they have been perfect for me, but I generally keep my lights lower, such as 10% for bedroom lighting, and around 60% for my kitchen. At 100%, it's more than bright enough for me. Colors look great, and make my home office way more comfortable. Using a setting like "energize" in the office helps my eyes feel less sore, I'm big on setting just the right color for working.

I have given these lights a 5, because I have never had an issue with the 10 total I have (and may be getting 4 more today), I've never had an issue between these bulbs and my phone apps Echo/Hue Hub, lighting is great and color is what I wanted in a bulb. I love smart-lights, and after testing cheaper ones, these have been much easter to work with (in my experience), and unlike my old ones they have always stayed connected to my apps. 3 years so far with never having to reconnect is a win for me. Just bear in mind, I can only speak to using Echo and Hue Hub with them.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2021
Data:
I have been wanting Philips Hue lights for about 10 years. Since they first came out. The day finally arrived when I had some extra money.

So I was very excited to try these. But from the time I turned these on, they have been a horrible experience.

I am an IT specialist that has been using a computer for 37 years. So if I have trouble setting these up, good luck...

Just finding the app was a nightmare because Google suggests unofficial apps instead, with the Philips app nowhere to be found. I actually had to type in a URL and it still went to the wrong address at first.

Their app doesn't even work with Android Marshmallow 6, so I had to use it with another smartphone,... because???

But I had already paired the light with that phone, so then I had to go through quite an adventure to get it working with my other phone. The lightbulb simply refused to work. It "rejected" being unpaired/paired. I would say that took about 2 hours.

After some struggle, finally, I had the other 2 lamps working with my phone, connected, now the real challenge had begun.

The lights are not unified in the scene, so if you pick a scene, the lights will be different colors. It never explains this. So I had two lamps on my desk which -- no matter what I did, they were different colors. It was so frustrating. I literally had to manually adjust one of them to match the other. Because by default, I guess people like their lamps to be different colors??? HAHAHA

You cannot even adjust the lights at the same time. For example if you wanted the 3 lights to change to a certain color and brightness, you have to adjust each one of them separately! Hahaha, what kind of smart app is this??

The app requires location to be turned on. HAHA, I'm using Bluetooth, I am literally right here where you are.. it would be impossible to control it over bluetooth if I wasn't standing before it. What kind of "smart" light is this.

Why do my light bulbs need my GPS location - are you serious? My location is not Philip's business.

Second, having location turned on to use your lamps means that all apps now have location turned on.

Third, this uses a lot more battery ... for what exactly, Philips?

Every time you open your phone, it will give you a location error. "These require location to be turned on," this is despite the fact that location is turned on... Luckily, it's just a momentary issue each time (a few seconds)

The lights are dim, it's like living inside a cave lit by a candle. The lights barely light themselves up. If you use scene "Bright" you can almost find your way around the room.

I guess they are somewhat adequate in the white settings, but leave a lot to be desired.

If you want color mode, the lights barely light themselves up. You can stare directly at the lightbulb with brightness turned to the max. Christmas tree lights are brighter than these!

I have no idea in the world how these are like $50 each.

Now let's talk about the updates. Every single time you open the app, there is some update. Seemingly because it never finishes them.

You have to update each light bulb individually!!! It won't just download the update to your phone and then begin installing to all or each light. Haha, no that would make too much sense!

It will download the update, and it takes about 12-24 hours, and if you do anything else, it will cancel the update, apparently.

It never gives you any clues like maybe you're not close enough to the light bulb, or ... what.

Is this the slowest CPU/processor in the world? Combined with the slowest storage in the world? I'm serious, it probably is! Sure, they have to cut costs somewhere, but this is absurdly slow. And you can tell because when you turn the light switch on, it takes about 2 seconds for the lights to come on!

I had left my phone on the entire night, plugged in with the screen on, and when I woke up it was still updating one of the bulbs. 8 hours later, it says "finalizing update" and it was stuck there. Like maybe now I can never use the light again. I am literally in the dark here. Then I realized I had it it switched off!

2 days later, now it's time to update the 2nd bulb! YAY torture!

Black Friday deal or not, I will almost certainly return these and never buy a Hue product again.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2022
Data:
When I started incorporating smart devices into my home a few years ago, one of the earliest devices I added was a Philips Hue Bridge and two Hue color bulbs. As the years went by I added more devices from other brands, including other-brand WiFi color bulbs that were much less expensive than the Hue bulbs. However the cheaper WiFi bulbs started showing their cons, as I would experience random lost connections, every few months I had to reset one or two of them, and of all the other devices I had in my Smart Home, the WiFi bulbs were what gave me the most trouble.

Then I realized - this whole time that I've been using Smart home devices, I never - ever - had an issue with the Hue bulbs! With that in mind, I decided to pick up a pack of 4 Hue bulbs to finally get rid of the cheaper, unreliable WiFi bulbs that I couldn't stand anymore. Sure enough, with the Hue bulbs installed, I have had zero issues with the lights. If I had just stuck with Hue from the beginning I wouldn't have wasted about $80 on inferior WiFi bulbs. So if you want reliable, high-quality color bulbs for your Smart home, go with Philips Hue. They are indeed worth the premium price.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2023
Data:
The lights are bright and the color is very vibrant. They are also responsive.... when they work. So far, every time the internet resets or anything changes, it takes about 2 or 3 hours of playing around in the app to try and get them to work with Google home. It's advertised as "seamless" integration but it absolutely IS NOT. They also HEAVLY try to make you buy a $60 "bridge" to connect the bulbs to Google home which is outrageous, considering the older bulbs (that used Wiz) never needed a bridge and would ACTUALLY connect seamlessly. You can connect without one, but you'll be spending several hours factory resetting devices, and uninstalling and re-installing apps and sometimes, they just decide they don't wanna work right until you spend another 3 hours. Between the 3 or 4 times I've had to battle with these things to try and get Google home to be able to discover them, then actually be able to connect to them I've probably factory reset the bulbs and my Google home about 5 times before they'd show up.

Overall a nice bulb but setting up is a CHORE and the "seamless" integration is very misleading when they try their best to force you to buy a $60 accessory you don't actually need unless your whole house is set up with several of these things.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2019
Data:
So first let's start off with the light and not the technology. it's great wonderful colors that you can get on these bulbs and that's the best part about it. Going down to probably what is 2200 k That's a really warm orange color that allows you to really feel relaxed especially when dim down. And then you can scale that up to somewhere around 4,000 k or something a little more stimulating or if you really need some kind of bright bright color turn all the way up to 6500 k. I love that aspect about this bulbs and that's the best thing about them.

Now it's dive into why this only gets three stars. first I almost want to give this 1 and 1/2 stars for the false advertising. this does not work with the Google Assistant which is stated in this Amazon listing as well as printed on the box. It does not work with the Google Assistant. It only works with the Google home. Only way that this works with the Google Assistant is to get the Philips hub. Anyone that's buying the Bluetooth is buying it because I don't want the hub. so if I could give this two and a half stars I would because I don't like false advertising and I bought these because I wanted it to work with my Google Assistant and not have to get the hub.

Second multiple user setup is very complicated even for someone like me running my own tech company setting up advanced networks. there's conflicting information out there and I actually had to call Phillips to figure this out because even he had to ask an advanced tech because they had conflicted information in the office.

To summarize, this is a subpar beta product that should never have been released to the public. Don't advertise that it works with something when it doesn't. and for the price of these bulbs it better work with the Google Assistant and have much more seamless setup. That said, everything is in context and then the smart light world there isn't anything great yet so this is why I bumped it up to three stars and because I really do like the color and the lighting and that's where Phillip's really does come through

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2019
Data:
I stayed up until 4:30 am trying to figure out how to work this new lightbulb with my new Echo Dot 3. First, you have to ignore the directions that came with the bulb. They were useless and misleading and one of the reasons I've been up half the night. No, you do not need a pricey Hue hub. You don't need the google playstore or the Apple store to download an app. You don't need to select "Hue" from the Alexa Skills menu and you don't need to sign up for a Hue account.

All you do is set up your Echo Dot if not already done. You should probably wait while it connects to your other devices. Then screw in the lightbulb and turn on the lamp/light fixture. At this point, Alexa should say new light found, but it didn't. I had to say "Alexa discover devices" Alexa named the device "First Light" Then I was able to say turn on first light, turn off first light, dim first light. There is a video on this page that tells you the exact same thing. This is the video to follow. I just wish there had been directions with this lightbulb that said how to hook it up with an Alexa device and I hadn't wasted hours of my time.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2020
Data:
Some friends had a few of these Hue color changing bulbs and at first i thought it was kinda gimmicky. I'm not one to get too much into techy gadgets but my wife and i decided to give it a try. Now i'm addicted and have 6 of the philips hue color changing bulbs in the living room, 1 of the color changing rope lights around the back of the tv, and 2 of the philips hue white bulbs in the bedroom.

They are AWESOME.

Aside from being fun to change the colors manually, you can choose from a bunch of preset color "themes". You can also create your own color theme and save it as a preset. There's also something called the Philips Hue Labs and that has various features you can use too, some of which i'll probably never use but some are useful.

One feature we really like is the ability to set "routines" which is basically a timer for the lights. You can set routines to do the same on/off every day, every other day, any combination of days and times, and it has a "random" feature that mixes up the on/off time so it's not exactly the same every time. We were using the inexpensive plastic white mechanical timers plugged in to outlets and lamps, but those are a thing of the past now. I just set up a bunch of routines if we go out of town. So so so good.

So there you go. We LOVE these lights. The app you get is also excellent and easy to set up and navigate.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2023
Data:
It used to be, and in fact still is with my old hue lights, that if you turned off the switch and turned it back on it would reset to the default white light, which I liked. Now if you flick the standard switch on and off, it diverts back to the last state, no matter what state you select in the settings of that bulb on the app. I searched far and wide as to how to correct this issue, because sometimes instead of going to my app to turn a light on that i turned off using my app, I just want a fast way to turn the light on, which used to just be flick the standard light switch on and off. I turns out, you can still do this, but you need to count 20 seconds after you flick the switch off, and the light will turn on when you flick the switch on again.

To explain more, when all the lights are off and i flick the standard switch on and off fast, only my old lights turn on. The new lights remain off, unless I wait 20 seconds before flicking the switch on. I don't know who thought that would be better.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2022
Data:
I bought two of these to add to the ones I already had. I don't do anything fancy, basically use them on a timed schedule. On before sunset and off at sunrise. Once you have the Hue bridge, then this is the cheapest remote control lighting solution. The other plus is that I do not want another account on the cloud, like almost all the other solutions, that can be hacked into.
The plan was to add these to my outdoor lamp fixtures. I had already set up my time schedule for the bulbs I already had. To make things easy, I plugged each one into a lamp socket indoors, then added them using their serial number and the Hue bridge found them in seconds.
I added them to the existing scene, tested to see if the would turn on and off and after that I went outdoors to screw them into the outdoor lamp sockets.
The whole procedure took less than 10 minutes. Could not be happier.
The price now is almost half of what they used to cost, another plus.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Data:
These bulbs were a little tricky to set up in the Hue app using Bluetooth, mostly due to an unstable Bluetooth connection. The app offers lots of control, once you figure out how it works. But for the life of me, I couldn't make it connect to my Google Home speaker. Google tech support knew a lot and spent lots of time on the phone with me, but we couldn't solve it. Phillips tech support was pretty close to useless. Finally, I figured out that there's a setting in the Hue app that makes the bulb discoverable. I'd tell you where it is, but I can't find it again. Anyway, once I made it discoverable, the Google Home app found it right away and connected it by Bluetooth to my speaker. It seemed pretty good for the first day.
.
Over time, I came to understand that my Bluetooth connections were extremely unstable, both between my phone and the bulbs and between the Google Home speaker and the bulbs. Every time a bulb lost a connection, it dimmed and then came back on. It gets old and annoying right away. After a day of this nonsense, my Google speaker lost its grip and never succeeded in doing anything with either of the bulbs. After a couple of days, I gave up and ordered a pair of GE "Cync" bulbs, which set up without a hitch and seem to be working great at a fraction of the cost.
.
I hear good things from others about these Phillips Hue bulbs when connected through a switch. But in my experience, these aren't good for Bluetooth only.

Data:
Ok, I said seamless. It does take a little effort to learn how to setup the bulbs in the app, link to Alexa and to other control apps.

I have more than 28 devices in my Smart Home. I have tried numerous bulbs from different manufacturers. My first set of bulbs came with the hub. Once I had the bulbs connected to the hub and configured in the Hue app and in Alexa, I haven't experienced any issues that were common with other bulb types.

I use them in my bedroom to automatically turn on when getting ready for bed and turn off after a preset time period. I like the fade feature after five minutes to gently turn off the lights. I can easily control them with a command to Alexa, use the Hue app, my Samsung Smart Things app on my phone and even on my watch!
